Higher education in Andorra started in 1988 with two faculties: the School of Nursing and the School of Computer Systems. The University of Andorra was formally created by law in July 1997. Now, the University of Andorra is constituted by public centres devoted to higher education.

Founded 1617 as School by Archbishop Paris Lodron, became University 1622, dissolved 1810. Re-established 1962. A State institution financed by the Federal Ministry of Education, Science and Culture.

Description: Founded in 2004 on the authority of the Government of the Kingdom of Bahrain and is a constituent university of the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland. Graduates of the University are awarded degrees from both the Medical University of Bahrain and the National University of Ireland. In addition, graduates in medicine also receive Licentiates from the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland and the Royal College of Physicians of Ireland. The degrees awarded by RCSI Bahrain are recognised and attested by the Higher Education Council in Bahrain

Founded by King William I of the Netherlands in 1817. The official language of the University was originally Latin; this changed to French in 1830 and to Dutch in 1930. Ghent University is today one of the most important academic institutions of Belgium and has an important international educational and scientific role. Acquired present status and title 1991.

Founded under King William I of the Netherlands in 1817. Designated as a State University following the independence of Belgium in 1835. Provision was made in 1959 for the transfer of the University to a new campus. The University enjoys limited autonomy and receives the major share of its income from the Communauté française de Belgique

University: Júlio de Mesquita Filho São Paulo State University

Streets: C.P. 6194 Rua da Reitoria, 121  Cidade Universitária 'Zeferino Vaz' Barão Geraldo
Description: Founded 1962 by the State legislature of São Paulo as an autonomous institution.

Streets: Rua da Reitoria 109 Cidade Universitária Butantã
Description: USP was founded in 1934 following the unification of several pre-existing schools. The newly created Faculty of Philosophy, Languages and Literature, and Human Sciences of the State of São Paulo were integrated along with the schools of Law, Medicine, Engineering, Pharmacy, Dentistry, Education, Economics and Veterinary Medicine as well as Luiz de Queiroz College of Agriculture. In the early days, many professors were invited from overseas to lecture, and they brought with them new standards of research from Europe. They assisted in transforming USP into a vital driving force for national progress, and, during the first twenty years of its existence, the University established several new schools. Subsequently, the University has expanded both in the quality of its output and in its size, adding the Institute of Biology in São Paulo and the campuses of São Carlos and Ribeirão Preto in the 1950s. Finally, in 1960, in the city of São Paulo, a new University campus, the Cidade Universitária was inaugurated. This resulted in the unification of the majority of the schools and faculties in one location
Founded 2007
Founded 1995, incorporating the former Higher Institute of Medicine and Higher Institute of Animal Production and Veterinary Medicine. Three Medical Colleges affiliated to Trakia University 1997

Founded 1802 as Saint Mary's College, acquired present status and title 1841. From 1970, a public, non-denominational institution.
Founded 1887 in Toronto and located in Hamilton 1930. A non-denominational private foundation.

Founded 1841 by Royal Charter issued by Queen Victoria. Modelled on the University of Edinburgh, Scottish academic influences have helped to mould its character. A national institution privately endowed and privately controlled.

Founded 1948 as Ryerson Institute of Technology, became Ryerson Polytechnic Institute 1963 and acquired present status and title 1993. Ryerson combines a traditional focus on theory with career-oriented emphasis on applicable skills-through laboratory work, field trips, outside projects, work experience, internships, regular contact with business and industry and work experience in the professional community.
Founded 1848 as College of Bytown, became College of Ottawa 1933. Acquired present status and title 1965.
Founded 1959. Established originally as affiliate of University of Toronto, the University moved to Glendon campus 1961. The University has 4 campuses in the City of Toronto.
Founded 1974 by the merger of Sir George Williams University, founded 1948, and Loyola College of Montreal, incorporated 1896.
Founded 1954. Recognized as a Catholic University through a decree 1957.
Founded 1911 as Regina College, Reorganized 1925 as University of Saskatchewan, 1959 as University of Saskatchewan, Regina Campus, and acquired present status and title 1974.

Founded 1888 by decree of Archbishop of Santiago. Recognized by Pope Leo XIII 1889; became Pontifical University 1930. A private, autonomous institution, with degrees recognized by Chilean Law. Financially supported by State subsidy and tuition fees

Part of 211 Project and 985 Project universities. Main administrative body: Ministry of Education

Description: Founded 1989. Acquired present status 1992

Founded 1348 by King Charles IV. Became a State institution 1773 when the Society of Jesus was dissolved. Divided in 1882 into separate Czech and German universities each bearing the title Charles-Ferdinand. Present title adopted 1918. Closed in November 1939 during the German occupation; reopened 1945 at which time the German university was abolished. Acquired present status 1999. Was previously know as Charles University in Prague (Univerzita Karlova v Praze).

Founded as Czech State Engineering School in 1707. Became Polytechnic in 1803. Granted university status in 1864. Closed in 1939 during the German occupation. Reopened in 1945. A State institution. Acquired present status in 1999.

Founded in 1919 with Faculties of Law, Medecine, Science and Arts; Faculty of Education established in 1947, Economics and Administration in 1990, Informatics in 1994, Social Studies in 1998 and Sports Studies in 2002. Closed 1939-1945 during the German occupation. Became Jan Evangelista Purkyně University in 1960; Renamed Masaryk University again since 1989.
Founded 1972 by Government decree. A State Institution employing new teaching and learning methods based on an 'integrated' approach to higher education and placing emphasis on group work

Founded 2000 following merger of Hawassa College of Agriculture (ACA), Dilla College of Teachers Education and Health Sciences (DCTEHS) and Wondo Genet College of Forestry (WGCF). Previously known as Debub University. Acquired present title 2006
Founded 1999 through amalgamation of Jimma College of Agriculture (founded 1952) and Jimma Institute of Health Sciences (founded 1983).
Created 1998 as St. Mary's College and became a university in 2013 after HERQA's evaluation
Created 1965 as an academy by the Faroese Parliament. Reorganised as a university in 1987.

Founded 1968. Acquired present status 1970. It is jointly owned by the governments of 12 member countries: Cook Islands, Fiji, Kiribati, Marshall Islands, Nauru, Niue, Solomon Islands, Tokelau, Tonga, Tuvalu, Vanuatu and Samoa.

Founded 1992. Acquired present title 2007, following merger with Haaga ammattikorkeakoulu (Haaga Polytechnic). Formerly known as Helsingin liiketalouden ammattikorkeakoulu Helsingfors yrkeshögskola för företagsekonomi (Helsinki Business Polytechnic).

Founded as Royal Academy of Turku 1640. Transferred to Helsinki 1828. The first and only university in the country until 1919.  The University of Helsinki is part of the Seinäjoki University Consortium (UCS) which brings together  University of Tampere, Helsinki University of the Arts - Sibelius Academy, University of Vaasa, University of Turku, the University Association of South Ostrobothnia, the Natural Resources Institute Finland and the Migration Institute of Finland. The Seinäjoki University Consortium is one of six university consortia in Finland and is coordinate by Tampere University

Founded 1863 as the first Finnish-speaking teacher training college, Jyväskylä Teacher Seminary. JYU became Jyväskylä College of Education in 1934 and acquired its present status and title, University of Jyväskylä, in 1966. The University of Jyväskylä is part of the Kajaani University Consortium (KUC) a networked academic community focused on scientific research, university teaching and community relations. The Kajaani University Consortium consists of four networked universities (Eastern Finland, Lapland, Jyväskylä and Oulu) that have units in Kajaani and Sotkamo. The Consortium is coordinated by University of Oulu.

Founded 1979. A State institution. The University of Lapland is part of the Kajaani University Consortium (KUC)  a networked academic community focused on scientific research, university teaching and community relations. The Kajaani University Consortium consists of four networked universities (Eastern Finland, Lapland, Jyväskylä and Oulu) that have units in Kajaani and Sotkamo. The Consortium is coordinated by University of Oulu. University of Lapland is also member of the University of the Arctic (Uartic), a network of over 200 universities, colleges, research institutes and other organizations concerned with education and research in and about the North

Founded 1968 as private School of Economics and Business Administration. Became state institution 1977. Acquired present status and title 1991. The University of Vaasa is part of the Seinäjoki University Consortium (UCS) which brings together University of Tampere, Helsinki University of the Arts - Sibelius Academy, University of Turku, the University Association of South Ostrobothnia, the Natural Resources Institute Finland and the Migration Institute of Finland. The Seinäjoki University Consortium is one of six university consortia in Finland and is coordinate by Tampere University
Founded 1971

Founded as experimental academic centre 1969. Moved to Saint Denis 1980. Member of the Community of Universities and Institutions - COMUE Université Paris-Lumières (Décret n° 2014-1677 - 29 décembre 2014)

Created 2006 following the merger between 'Tbilisi 'Ilia Čavčavadze' State University of Languages and Culture' (Tbilisis 'Ilia Čavčavadzis' Sakhelobis Enata da Kulturata Sakhelmtsipo Universiteti, founded 1948) and Tbilisi Sulkhan-Saba Orbeliani State Pedagogical University (Tbilisis Sulkhan-Saba Orbelianis Sakhelobis Sakhelmtsipo Pedagogiuri Universiteti, founded 1935). Previously known as Ilia Čavčavadze Sakhelmtsipo Universiteti (Ilia Čavčavadze State University). Acquired present title 2010

The first-ever national university in the Caucasus was founded and opened in Tbilisi in 1918 laying the foundation for a European-type higher school in Georgia, based on Georgian educational traditions. The idea of foundation of an university first emerged as far back as the early 19th century amid intensification of the struggle for liberation from Russian empire. The first-ever national University in the Caucasus was opened on 26 January 1918, the day of commemoration of King David the Builder (new style 8 February). Upon the nomination of Ivane Javakhishvili, the Council of Professors elected Petre Melikishvili as the first rector of the university. Ivane Javakhishvili took charge of the faculty of philosophy. Tbilisi State University is one of the largest higher educational institutions in the South Caucasus

New Vision University is a civic, non-profit private institution founded in 2013. NVU mission is to expand human vision through promotion of education, research and innovation. The university inspires individuals to advance and share knowledge, skills and values to contribute to the well-being of the society. NVU is committed to social responsibility and promotes equal access to education to students from around the world. NVU is aspired to create open, innovative and collaborative environment to ensure student engagement and serve the society on a national and international scale

Founded 1386 by Rupert I, Elector of the Palatinate. The character of the University was profoundly affected by the Renaissance and the Reformation. It was reorganized as an independent institution by the Grand Duke Charles Frederick of Baden in 1803 and is now an autonomous University financially supported by the State of Baden-Württemberg, and under the jurisdiction of its Ministry of Science and Art.

Founded 1810 as Friedrich-Wilhelms-Universität. Reorganized 1946 and renamed 1948 Humboldt-Universität zu Berlin. Faculty structure replaced under 1968 reform by series of subject sections, and replaced following reunification 1990. An independent institution financially supported by the 'Land' of Berlin.

Founded 1946 as a teacher training college, acquired university status in the late 1970s. Today integrates two formerly independent institutions of higher education – the University of Lüneburg and the University of Applied Sciences. Became a foundation under public law – the highest degree of autonomy awarded to public universities - 2003
Founded 962. A State institution enjoying administrative autonomy.

Founded 1887 as 'Tetsugaku-kan' (Academy of Philosophy). Became University and acquired present title 1906. Campuses are located in downtown Tokyo (main campus) and its vicinity (3 other campuses). It is a comprehensive university, consisting of 11 faculties and 44 departments, with a total of approximately 30,000 students.

Established in 1872 as modern Japan's first national institute of higher education, which started as the Normal School, later renamed Tokyo Higher Normal School, the first teachers' college in Japan. Became Tokyo University of Education in 1947. Reorganized as a comprehensive research university in Tsukuba Science City in 1973. Merged with University of Library and Information Science in 2002. In 2004, Japanese national universities were transformed into national university corporations (NUCs).

Streets: Km. 2.5 Carretera a Acatlima  Ciudad Universitaria
Description: Created in 1990, the Technological University of the Mixteca is part of the Oaxaca State University System (SUNEO). SUNEO was created to serve as a cultural instrument for the transformation of the social environment. This can be achieved through high – performance universities, which create a comparative advantage for the State of Oaxaca and make it attractive for productive investments. It is aimed at contributing to the decentralization of high quality higher education services in the following substantive functions: Teaching, Research, Cultural Diffusion and Development promotion.  The SUNEO Project started in 1988 and at the beginning of 1990, the activities began with the Technological University of the Mixteca (UTM). In 1992, the University of the Sea (UMAR) was created and the project was extended to a new socio- cultural and environmental reference point in Oaxaca: the Oaxacan coast, with the aim of promoting the culture of the sea. During the first decade of the 21st century, the project was extended throughout the state, expanding the educational offerings in the field of science and technology and developing scientific and technological research and creating many services for the people of Oaxaca. SUNEO is made up of ten universities on eighteen campus distributed throughout all regions of Oaxaca. The campus are scalable to meet demand: Technological University of the Mixteca (UTM-Huajuapan), University of the Sea (UMAR-Puerto Escondido, Puerto Ángel, Huatulco and Oaxaca campus), University of the Isthmus (UNISTMO-Tehuantepec, Ixtepec, Juchitán Campus), University of Papaloapan (UNPA- Tuxtepec and Loma Bonita Campus), University of Sierra Sur (UNSIS-Miahuatlán), University of Sierra Juárez (UNSIJ-Ixtlán), University of La Cañada (UNCA-Teotitlán de Flores Magón), NovaUniversitas (Ocotlán, San Jacinto and Juxtlahuaca Campus), University of the Coast (UNCOS- Pinotepa Nacional) and University of Chalcatongo (UNICHA-Chalcatongo de Hidalgo). Additional campus are under construction. At this time, SUNEO has around 1,100 full-time professors. More than 10 thousand students. 30 Research Institutes, 183 Laboratories and 29 Workshops. The SUNEO offers 87 Bachelor’s degrees, most of them are engineering and 41 Postgraduate programs: 10 Doctorates and 31 Masters. The SUNEO covers a total of 516 hectares

Streets: Apartado postal 272 Avenida Universidad, 333 Col. Las Víboras

The SUNEO Project started in 1988 and at the beginning of 1990, the activities began with the Technological University of the Mixteca (UTM). In 1992, the University of the Sea (UMAR) was created and the project was extended to a new socio- cultural and environmental reference point in Oaxaca: the Oaxacan coast, with the aim of promoting the culture of the sea. During the first decade of the 21st century, the project was extended throughout the state, expanding the educational offerings in the field of science and technology and developing scientific and technological research and creating many services for the people of Oaxaca. Today, the SUNEO is made up of ten universities on eighteen campus distributed throughout all regions of Oaxaca. Founded 1911, as a result of the newly implanted republican system. However, it stems, since the 18th century, from many combined experiences of training in Science, Arts and Medicine, which would lead to the future University. The university has three main sites known as Polos spreading out all over the city of Porto (Polo I – downtown; Polo II Asprela (northern Porto); Polo III Campo Alegre (western bank, river Douro) and a fourth site outside the city, in Vairão. The U.Porto is composed of 14 Organic Units of Education and Research called faculties or institutes. Their mission includes education, research and the provision of services in their specific area of competence. The University of Porto is an important driving force for economic, social, cultural and scientific development in Northern Portugal and in the country as a whole

Established in 1836 as a secular alternative to Oxford and Cambridge, the only two other English universities at the time, University of London became the first to explicitly exclude religious qualification as an entry requirement. It is also the first University to give external students the opportunity to continue to earn a living while studying, and to study privately and take exams without coming to London. Since then, University of London has expanded and modernised, becoming a pioneering institution that was the first to make higher education available to women and those unable to pursue traditional forms of study. Today, UoL has 120,000 students on campuses in London and 50,000 in 190 countries taking UoL degrees transnationally. It comprises a federation of central academic bodies, member institutions and research institutes that include world leaders in their fields: Birkbeck, University of London; City, University of London; Courtauld Institute of Art; Goldsmiths, University of London; Institute of Cancer Research; King's College London, London Business School, London School of Economics and Political Science; London School of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine; Queen Mary University of London; Royal Academy of Music; Royal Central School of Speech and Drama; Royal Holloway, University of London; Royal Veterinary College; School of Advanced Study; School of Oriental and African Studies; St George's, University of London; UCL; and University of London Institute in Paris
